clinical_study.brief_title: Imaging and Understanding BOS in Lung Transplantation
clinical_study.official_title: Imaging and Understanding BOS in Lung Transplantation

brief_summary.textblock: This study is a prospective, non-randomized, longitudinal, observational study that will recruit about 5 lung transplant patients per year for 3 years.

detailed_description.textblock: This study is a prospective, non-randomized, longitudinal, observational study that will recruit about 5 lung transplant patients per year for 3 years. We will follow these patients at 6 months and 1 year with Hyperpolarized Helium-3 Magnetic Resonance Imaging and image guided bronchial biopsies to detect early BOS and to better understand BO disease progression. The biopsies will provide future research for rapid determination of cellular and molecular mechanisms that lead to BOS and to facilitate identification and validation of translatable pharmaceutical targets.

primary_outcome.measure: Analysis of MRI imaging to detect BOS compared to biopsy
primary_outcome.description: Analysis of MRI imaging to detect BOS compared to biopsy

arm_group.description: Hyperpolarized Helium-3 MRI. Subjects who have had or are scheduled to have a lung transplant

intervention.description: Subjects will inhale Hyperpolarized Helium-3 gas during the MRI. This gas enhances images and the data collected will be used to determine if it can be used to detect BOS earlier than current standard of care.

biospec_descr.textblock: Biopsies of transplanted and explanted lung tissue

study_pop.textblock: Subjects who have had or are scheduled for lung transplant

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Lung Transplantation within the last 10 years or being assessed for possible lung transplantation.
- Male or female
- 0 to 25 years of age.
Exclusion Criteria:
- Standard MRI exclusion criteria as set forth by the CCHMC Division of Radiology
- Inability to perform 10 second breath hold for 3He MRI scan
- Bleeding disorders

patient_data.ipd_description: There is no plan to share IPD with other researchers at this time. If this plan changes, no identifiable information will be shared.
